title: Sri Lanka has used 60-pct of USD 500 mln Indian fuel credit line – sources
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka has used up to 60 percent of the 500 million US dollar Indian fuel credit line so far and the remaining could be exhausted within this month, two sources familiar with the credit line said on Thursday.
The island nation got breathing space with the Indian fuel credit line as a severe shortage of dollars crippled Sri Lankan authorities from importing fuel.
“Around 60 percent of the fuel credit has been already used,” a source who has knowledge on the fuel deal told the Economy Next.

A separate government source said it will be difficult to purchase fuel after April 20 unless the government finds another credit line or make sharp policy changes including increasing interest rates to boost the reserves.

The government source said the Indian credit line is likely to exhaust around April 20 as the Sri Lankan government is expected to supply uninterrupted power during the festive season throughout next week through April 18.
Sri Lanka’s monthly fuel import bill has risen to 430 million US dollars due to higher consumption in the face of increased diesel usage for power generation and increased global oil prices.
The Indian credit line was originally scheduled to start from April 1, but India started to send the shipments from mid March after Sri Lanka’s fuel shortage aggravated. (Colombo/April 08/2022)
